content:
=== Game Rules ===
This is vgdl rule file:
BasicGame
  SpriteSet
    floor > Immovable randomtiling=0.9 img=oryx/floor3 hidden=True
    goal  > Door color=GREEN img=oryx/doorclosed1
    key   > Immovable color=ORANGE img=oryx/key2
    sword > OrientedFlicker limit=5 singleton=True img=oryx/slash1
    movable >
      avatar  > ShootAvatar   stype=sword frameRate=8
        nokey   > img=oryx/swordman1
        withkey > color=ORANGE img=oryx/swordmankey1
      enemy >  
        monsterQuick > RandomNPC cooldown=2 cons=6 img=oryx/bat1
        monsterNormal > RandomNPC cooldown=4 cons=8 img=oryx/spider2
        monsterSlow > RandomNPC cooldown=8 cons=12 img=oryx/scorpion1
      wall > Immovable autotiling=true img=oryx/wall3
      	

  LevelMapping
    g > floor goal
    + > floor key        
    A > floor nokey
    1 > floor monsterQuick
    2 > floor monsterNormal
    3 > floor monsterSlow
    w > wall
    . > floor
    

  InteractionSet
    movable wall  > stepBack
    nokey goal    > stepBack
    goal withkey  > killSprite scoreChange=1
    enemy sword > killSprite scoreChange=2
    enemy enemy > stepBack
    avatar enemy > killSprite scoreChange=-1
    nokey key     > transformTo stype=withkey scoreChange=1 killSecond=True

  TerminationSet
    SpriteCounter stype=goal   win=True
    SpriteCounter stype=avatar win=False
This is vgdl rule in natural language:
Here’s a plain‑language breakdown of what’s going on in this game:

1. Genre and Overall Feel:
 • It’s a puzzle-adventure game with real‑time action. You must navigate a maze‑like level while juggling objectives and dangers. There’s an element of “key and door” puzzles combined with combat against roaming enemies.

2. Game Mechanics:
 • You control an avatar that can shoot a “sword” (a temporary, oriented projectile) to defeat enemies.
 • The level is built from tiles (walls, floors, special objects), and some of these objects (like keys and doors) have specific roles.
 • The avatar starts out in a “nokey” state. When the avatar touches the key, it transforms into a “withkey” version and earns points.
 • You must have the key to interact properly with the goal (door). If you try to enter the door without the key, you’ll be blocked.
 • There are various enemies (or “monsters”) that move around randomly at different speeds. They can hurt you if you collide with them, although you have the option of shooting your sword to kill them for bonus points.
 • Some interactions cause sprites to “step back” (simulating a collision logic), while others can “kill” a sprite or transform it.
 • The game gives you score changes for making successful moves (picking up the key and killing enemies) but also penalizes you for getting hit by enemies.

3. Objectives and Win/Loss Conditions:
 • The primary objective is to get to the door (the “goal”). However, you can only complete the level by reaching it in the “withkey” state.
 • To reach that state, you must first grab the key (which transforms your avatar and gives you extra points).
 • Besides the key-door objective, you can also kill enemies with your sword. This rewards additional points and can help clear dangerous paths.
 • You win by removing (or “killing”) the goal sprite—essentially opening the door—meaning you’ve succeeded in finishing the level.
 • You lose if your avatar is eliminated (for example, by colliding with an enemy without the proper defenses).

4. Possible Overall Strategy:
 • Analyze the level layout to plan a safe path: know where walls, enemies, keys, and the door are.
 • First, navigate carefully to collect the key. Since your initial state is “nokey,” avoid going straight for the door (which won’t let you pass and simply makes you back off).
 • Use your sword attacks strategically to clear or distract roaming enemies if they block your safe path or pose too much risk.
 • Once you’ve collected the key (and transformed into “withkey”), work toward the goal door. Be cautious of enemies—remember that if the avatar touches an enemy, you risk losing points or dying.
 • Keep an eye on the pacing of enemy movements (they have different speeds and “cooldown” times) so that you can time your moves to avoid accidental collisions.
 • In summary: plan your route, grab the key, clear or evade enemies as needed, and then head for the door to win.

This breakdown should help you understand the genre (puzzle-adventure with action-combat elements), the key gameplay mechanics, and an overall approach for success in the game.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT
4: ACTION_DOWN
5: ACTION_UP

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game.

Action:4

I'm moving down from (5,1) to (6,1) to advance directly toward the door zone, keeping enemy threats in view for potential sword strikes if needed—all part of our aggressive withkey strategy.

=== Sprite Mapping ===
avatar -> 'a'
floor goal -> 'g'
floor key -> '+'
floor nokey -> 'A'
floor monsterQuick -> '1'
floor monsterNormal -> '2'
floor monsterSlow -> '3'
wall -> 'w'
floor -> '.'
goal -> '@'
key -> '#'
monsterNormal -> '$'
monsterQuick -> '%'
monsterSlow -> '&'
nokey -> '*'
withkey -> 'm'
